channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Former Prime Minister Tony Abbott is made president of the UK's Board of Trade
item.description: The 62-year-old will tasked with helping Britain strike trade deals around the world after leaving the European Union.

item.title: Brazilian congresswoman is accused of ordering the murder of her husband
item.description: Brazilian Congresswoman Flordelis de Souza has been charged with ordering the execution of her husband, pastor Anderson do Carmo after a row over their 55 children, many of whom are adopted.

item.title: BBC staff will be given diversity lessons to stop 'microaggessions'
item.description: BBC drama boss Piers Wenger told the Edinburgh TV Festival that he has been in 'deep discussion' about how to 'eradicate unconscious bias' to help improve the representation of ethnic minorities.

item.title: Victoria suffers a spike in coronavirus deaths as 24 patients die
item.description: Victoria has reported 149 new coronavirus cases with another 24 people dead - the second deadliest day since the pandemic began.

item.title: Harry Maguire maintains innocence and will appeal conviction
item.description: Maguire, 27, was given a 21-month suspended sentence after being found guilty of assault following his arrest after a brawl last week on the island of Mykonos.

item.title: Mum-of-two Jo Lloyd, 42, debuts her stunning new figure after she went from a size 20 to a size 6
item.description: Mum-of-two and self-confessed 'serial dieter' Jo Lloyd, from Victoria, has debuted her sensational new figure in a swimwear shoot, after she went from a size 18-20 to a slim size 6 in under a year.

item.title: Nottingham teenagers jailed a total of 20 years for boy's murder
item.description: Ezekiel Clarke was killed in February when he was stabbed several times in the arm, chest, heart, liver and lung during an attack on a street in Nottingham.

item.title: Young children of working parents had fewer tantrums in lockdown
item.description: Young children's concentration also improved according to the Co-Spyce study, a collaboration between multiple universities including Oxford.

item.title: PAUL THOMAS on... the Proms songs ban row
item.description: 'The face mask will remind you to never never never burst into any songs you may know'

item.title: Free London Dungeon entry to people with SERIAL KILLER names
item.description: Charity Victim Support said London dungeon's free entry offer for anyone with the same name as a British serial killers is disrespectful to the traumatised families of murder victims.

item.title: University of Queensland coronavirus trial vaccine produces zero side effects in humans, hamsters
item.description: A COVID-19 vaccine being developed by the University of Queensland has proven to produce no adverse effects on humans and hamsters.

item.title: STEPHEN WRIGHT looks back at how the Carl Beech scandal unfolded
item.description: STEPHEN WRIGHT Five years ago I flew to Gibraltar to meet a former Tory MP. He was in self-imposed exile after he had been accused of being a serial child killer in the UK.

item.title: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS reviews last night's TV
item.description: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS: Just about every bloke knows that hideous moment when his wife or partner says accusingly: 'You haven't even noticed, have you?'

item.title: Belarus jails two prominent activists
item.description: Olga Kovalkova and Siarhei Dyleuski were brought before separate courts and jailed as protests continued against the 26-year rule of President Alexander Lukashenko.

item.title: Donald Trump issues convention-eve pardon of Jon Ponder, a convicted bank robber
item.description: President Donald Trump on Tuesday announced he the pardon of Jon Ponder, a three-time felon and convicted bank robber who started nonprofit Hope For Prisoners.

item.title: Poor pupils are 18 months behind their classmates, report says
item.description: Analysis by the Education Policy Institute (EPI) found the attainment gap between poorer pupils in England and their wealthier classmates has stopped closing for the first time in a decade.

item.title: Dietitian shares the foolproof hack for tricking your brain into thinking it's full
item.description: An Australian dietitian has shared a foolproof hack for tricking your brain into thinking it's full - and all you need is a small bowl.

item.title: North Korea issues new pictures of leader Kim Jong-Un days after diplomat claimed he was in a coma
item.description: The dictator was shown at an enlarged meeting of the politburo of the Workers Party (pictured), the state-controlled Korean Central News Agency said.

item.title: Britain could buy only HALF of its targets of F35B Lighting 2 fighter jets
item.description: Plans for 138 jets could be scrapped but the UK has agreed to buy 48 by the end of 2025 as part of a £9.1billion deal. Pictured an F-35 Lightning II jet.

item.title: Vera Lynn's rendition of Land of Hope and Glory tops iTunes charts
item.description: Tweeting a version by the British national treasure, Fox wrote: 'Wouldn't it be great if we could all come together to get Dame Vera Lynn's version of "Land of Hope and Glory" number one in the charts?'

item.title: Ministers hope office screening for coronavirus might get more people back at their desks
item.description: Routine coronavirus testing could be introduced in offices and factories as part of a new Government drive to get more people back to work.

item.title: 300lb Colorado woman reveals how she lost HALF body weight
item.description: Michaela Miller, from Colorado, struggled with weight from an early age - but it spiraled out of control after her dad made cruel comments about her body.

item.title: UK school pupils WILL wear face masks if local area in lockdown
item.description: UK's Education Secretary Gavin Williamson last night said face coverings will be compulsory in the communal areas of schools covered by local lockdowns.

item.title: SARAH VINE: Look out, Sloanes - the Wokesters are coming for you!
item.description: SARAH VINE: One of my least favourite questions to be asked is: if I could go back in time and eliminate one person from history, who would it be?

item.title: BBC under fire from all sides for gagging Britannia
item.description: The BBC was today lambasted over its bungled decision to play Land of Hope and Glory and Rule Britannia without lyrics at the last Night of the Proms following a racism row, with TV bosses accused of 'erasing history' and caving in to 'woke morons'.

item.title: Wetherspoon pubs are running out of tomato ketchup due to popularity of Eat Out to Help Out
item.description: The popular UK pub chain (pictured, in Cornwall) was hit by 'high demand' and reduced supply after flooding at Heinz's factory during storms.

item.title: Don't let car sale scammers drive off with YOUR cash
item.description: Some 2,094 vehicle scams were reported to Action Fraud, the national fraud reporting service, in July alone - a 550 per cent increase compared with March.

item.title: Transgender woman undergoes eighth nose job
item.description: Maria, who is based in Los Angeles, consulted with Dr. Paul Nassif and Dr. Terry Dubrow on Monday night's episode of the E! reality series Botched.

item.title: New tool can automatically analyse dreams and finds they 'don't contain hidden messages'
item.description: Experts from the Nokia Bell Labs in Cambridge created a Natural Language Processing technique that can automatically analyse dreams and quantify them.

item.title: Giant crocodile killed 175-pound sloth 13 million years ago, fossils reveal
item.description: The 175-pound animal's shin from a hind leg was found in modern-day Peru in 2004 and analysis reveals it dates back to when the area was a proto-Amazonian wetland.

item.title: EXCLUSIVE Charli XCX's Chelsea home on sale for £2.4million
item.description: EXCLUSIVE The property, built in 1891, was recently refurbished by Charli XCX, 28 - who maintained many of the house's classic features while adding her own clean and contemporary twist.

item.title: Dog-sized dinosaur that lived 230 million years ago 'ancestor of Triceratops'
item.description: Analysis from Brazilian researchers found the Labrador-sized creature fits into the genetic history of dinosaurs at the very start of a branch known as ornithischians.

item.title: Sophie Wessex reveals her children are 'not into social media'
item.description: The mother-of-two to Lady Louise, 16, and James Viscount Severn, 12, said the virtual world can be 'unkind' and she hopes her 'open' relationship with her children will help them navigate it better.

item.title: Cambridge joins the coronavirus vaccine race
item.description: Researchers at the University of Cambridge say they avoided targeting the coronavirus's infamous spike proteins in a bid to make their vaccine safer, longer-lasting and it may even cover other viruses.

item.title: We'll meet again! Friendships that have dried up during lockdown will return to normal, expert says
item.description: Professor Robin Dunbar, of Oxford University, has spent 25 years studying behaviours in primates and human groups and applied his knowledge to the pandemic.

item.title: Property empire worth £17million gets seized
item.description: Industrial premises, terraced houses and even a public gym were among the 59 British addresses targeted by the National Crime Agency in an inquiry that began in 2011.

item.title: Gambling giants flout advertising rules to target children
item.description: The UK's Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) found that as many as 70 different betting ads from four gambling operators appeared on just eight websites used by youngsters.

item.title: SEBASTIAN SHAKESPEARE: TV arts supremo Alan Yentob secretly weds his love
item.description: SEBASTIAN SHAKESPEARE I can reveal that Yentob has finally married his TV producer girlfriend Philippa Walker after almost 40 years together.

item.title: Proof that Covid cowardice is killing a nation of shopkeepers
item.description: Dean Hooke (pictured) says office workers account for at least 80 per cent of the customers at his firm John W. Hooke & Son. His takings are down by the same margin on their pre-pandemic levels.

item.title: VICTORIA BISCHOFF: End Covid-19 blame game
item.description: I got a scam call claiming to be from PayPal. What is worrying is how difficult it is to contact the company. Firms need to stop treating the pandemic as if it's some sort of Get Out Of Jail Free card.

item.title: ASK TONY: Vodafone hit lonely Dad with four-figure bill
item.description: My 89-year-old father went way over his monthly call limit and, over three months, Vodafone has taken more than £1,000. This phone was his lifeline during isolation.

item.title: Aveva is Britain's most valuable software firm
item.description: The firm, which makes computer programmes used to design oil rigs, ships and nuclear power stations, is buying data company Osisoft.

item.title: Obese children are more likely to get multiple sclerosis
item.description: Experts at Queen Mary University of London and the University of Oxford say that one in ten cases of the condition are linked to people carrying excess weight as a child or teenager.

item.title: NASA satellite images show smoke over California amid wildfires
item.description: The Golden State is currently battling some of the worst wildfires in its history, and images from NASA's Terra satellite have revealed the devastating extent of the unprecedented inferno.

item.title: Harry Maguire found GUILTY and dropped from England squad
item.description: England defender and Manchester United captain Harry Maguire was today convicted of all charges after a brawl at the Greek holiday island of Mykonos.

item.title: Has your travel insurer taken you for a ride?
item.description: Buying travel insurance never used to be a nightmare. Most holidaymakers would run a comparison site search and buy the first affordable policy. But now the stakes are higher.

item.title: Children born at higher altitudes are smaller at birth and have stunted growth
item.description: A new study from International Food Policy Research Institute found children born in cities 5,000 feet or more above sea level were more likely to be smaller as infants and have stunted growth.

item.title: Meghan Markle sits down with Gloria Steinem for 'backyard chat' about voting
item.description: Meghan, 39, interviewed activist Gloria, 86, for a video for female empowerment platform Makers Women, which will be shared in full on Wednesday.

item.title: Local health officials in Charlotte warn Republican National Convention about lack of masks
item.description: A Mecklenburg County official contacted the RNC about lack of mask use and improper social distancing during the 'roll call' that nominated President Donald Trump at the GOP convention.

item.title: Alzheimer's zapped: Scientist launch landmark trial to treat dementia
item.description: A team at Imperial College London and the UK Dementia Research Institute have been given a $1.5million (£1.14million) grant by US philanthropists to trial the technology.

item.title: Historian Nigel Jones recounts the humbling of a colossus tank
item.description: November 1917, and the day dawned dank and foggy over the water-logged trenches near Cambrai in eastern France.

item.title: Cara Delevingne will explore her years of struggle with her sexual identity in a new BBC series
item.description: The model turned actress said she was 'excited' to be making the BBC3 programme 'as someone who struggled for years to understand my sexual identity'.

item.title: Britain's two-metre social distancing rule 'is based on outdated science'
item.description: The University of Oxford said the rule was over simplistic.and there should be a grading system depending on how 'risky' a place is. A bar, pub or nightclub would be deemed high risk.

item.title: BBC's documentary Carl Beech is branded a 'cover-up' over the corporation's own role in the scandal
item.description: A BBC documentary on VIP abuse fantasist Carl Beech was branded a 'cover-up' last night for failing to properly acknowledge the corporation's own role in the scandal.

item.title: AI algorithm discovers FIFTY new exoplanets orbiting far-off stars by analyzing NASA data
item.description: A new machine-learning algorithm discovered 50 new exoplanets beyond our solar system. This is the first time AI has validated planets. Some are larger than Neptune with 200 day-long orbits.

item.title: SpaceX: Successful 'static fire' test of Starship rocket prototype
item.description: SpaceX lit up SN6 Starship prototype's Raptor Engine during a static fire trial, releasing bursts of fire and smoke from the base - it was, however, the third attempt of the test.

item.title: Kent girl, eight, who was killed by falling tree is named as family pay tribute to 'beautiful niece'
item.description: Maisy Mayne, who was just eight, was struck along a footpath in a field in Bobbing, near Sittingbourne in Kent (pictured).

item.title: Alaska AG resigns over hundreds of texts sent to female employee
item.description: Attorney General Kevin Clarkson, 61, sent his resignation letter to Gov Mike Dunleavy Tuesday after it was revealed he had sent a junior state employee 558 text messages back in March.

item.title: Tom Cruise shares fun video of himself touring London in a taxi as he sneaks into a busy cinema
item.description: The actor, 58, who donned a protective face mask during the footage amid the Covid-19 crisis, also sneaked into a busy cinema to watch Tenet.

item.title: Mother-of-three warns parents over crib after her six-month-old baby slipped down gap
item.description: Leanne Cregg, from Burnley, Lancashire, claims a co-sleeping travel cot has a serious design flaw after her baby Freya slipped down a gap between the crib and the bed.

item.title: Workers at Cosmopolitan casino in Las Vegas claim it is 'the Wuhan of the strip'
item.description: Ten anonymous workers told The Daily Beast they are 'terrified' they will catch COVID-19 working at the reopened casino where gamblers refuse to social distance and management fail to enforce protocols.

item.title: Shortcut to glamour ISN'T beyond the fringe!
item.description: GEORGE NORTHWOOD: There's no better way to freshen up a tired face or disguise a wrinkled forehead than a fringe; done properly, it can take years off your look.

item.title: Kate and Rio Ferdinand 'splash out £40,000 on two highly-trained protection dogs for their home'
item.description: The celebrity couple, who are expecting their first baby together this year, are said to want extra security at their mansion for their growing family.

item.title: Roman Polanski loses court case over expulsion from Academy Awards body
item.description: Polanski, 87, who won an Oscar in 2003, was expelled by the Academy in May 2018 because of the long-standing criminal case which dates back to 1977, City News Service in LA reported.

item.title: IAN LADYMAN: Southgate left looking foolish after picking Maguire but will his players ever learn?
item.description: IAN LADYMAN: By 5.30pm on Tuesday night, most if not all of what Gareth Southgate had earlier said about Harry Maguire had been rendered completely and spectacularly redundant.

item.title: America's toxic choice: TOM LEONARD examines the upcoming US election campaign
item.description: TOM LEONARD: Jacob Blake, 29, lies in hospital paralysed from the waist down after Sunday's shooting in Wisconsin. The two nights of protests that followed saw buildings and cars set alight.

item.title: Insurers unfairly rejecting claims for cancelled weddings
item.description: Teachers Lidia Szmid, 30, and partner Adam Burton, 32, went to battle with UK General Insurance after their wedding venue in Chichester had to close in April.

item.title: Teenagers to get Gordon Brown's freebie trust fund cash
item.description: They will be the first to get their hands on Child Trust Fund cash given to them when they were born. Emily Fletcher (pictured) plans to keep her money invested when her child trust fund matures.

item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell loses bid to get out of solitary confinement
item.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan denied Ghislaine Maxwell's request to be moved out of solitary confinement to the general population at Brooklyn prison on Tuesday.

item.title: If the BBC knew its history, it would understand Rule Britannia ISN'T racist, writes ROBERT HARDMAN
item.description: Not even the finest dairy herds of Devon and Cornwall could have confected something as thick, rich and clotted as the latest solution served up by the BBC.

item.title: Sad claims Renate attempted suicide on honeymoon with Elton John, writes ALISON BOSHOFF
item.description: In his autobiography, published last year and entitled Me, he wrote that Renate had been 'decent and dignified' about the end of the marriage after four years.

item.title: Jonathan Ross's daughter Honey slams diets suggested by parents
item.description: Making an appearance on Tuesday's edition of Loose Women, the writer and activist, 23, said she found the incident 'absolutely toxic', and encouraged parents not to do what hers did with their children.

item.title: Coronavirus: London man stranded on Samoan island til Christmas
item.description: Back in March, Rob Small, from London, was enjoying his time on the white sand and palm-fringed shores of Upolu in Samoa. But when coronavirus started to spread, all international travel was banned.

item.title: Man, 30, charged with knife murder of brother found by roadside
item.description: Samuel Rogers, 30, was charged alongside a second man, 22-year-old Ryan Hurt, in connection with the death of his younger brother Thomas, 26, in Birmingham on Saturday.

item.title: Art vandal who punched hole in Pablo Picasso's £20m Bust of a Woman is jailed for 18 months
item.description: Shakeel Ryan Massey who punched a hole in Picasso's £20million Bust of a Woman painting for 'five minutes of fame' has been jailed for 18 months at Inner London Crown Court today.

item.title: Jacob Blake is paralyzed from the waist down, his father says
item.description: Jacob Blake, the black man shot in the back by Wisonsin police as his three young sons watched on, is now paralyzed from the waist down after his body was riddled with bullets, his father says.

item.title: Police officer accused of asking vulnerable woman for threesome
item.description: Darren Booth, 40, told a misconduct hearing that he denied ever asking a woman, known as Miss A, for sex after he was called to deal with anti-social behaviour in Castleford.

item.title: Burial ground containing 350 people in tiny circular graves is unearthed in Japan
item.description: The site - dubbed the 'Umeda Tomb' - is located in Osaka and is thought to be one of seven historical grave sites located across the city.

item.title: Harry Dunn: Alleged killer Anne Sacoolas may be tried online
item.description: The Dunn family's MP, Andrea Leadsom, wrote to Government ministers on August 10 asking for them to consider the possibility of Anne Sacoolas standing trial while she is still in the US.

item.title: Canadian woman, 44, is mauled to death by black bear outside family cabin
item.description: Stephanie Blais, 44, was on the phone with her dad when the bear attacked on Thursday outside the cabin at Mckie Lake, near Buffalo Falls.

item.title: North Yorks Police warn over drugs-laced 'Nerds Rope sweets'
item.description: North Yorkshire Police said parents and carers should be 'aware' of a rise in youths found with 'edibles' disguised as Nerds candy.

item.title: Man arrested on suspicion of murder after body found at tip
item.description: The freezer was moved from a flat in Birmingham to a waste management centre by a housing association before the body was discovered.

item.title: Julian Assange's partner says he is in 'a lot of pain'
item.description: Stella Moris took the couple's two children Gabriel, three, and Max, one, to visit their father at the south-east London prison for the first time since March 22.

item.title: Grandson of man who killed his wife in 1985 says he should never be released from prison
item.description: Russell Causley killed his wife Carole Packman 35 years ago and now he is facing a parole hearing, but his grandson says that he should never be released from prison.

item.title: Drunk chef, 22, died of 'catastrophic' head injuries after falling from railway platform onto tracks
item.description: Carrie Bremridge, from Merstham in Surrey, had been drinking with friends at a pub and attended a house party in January. She stumbled and fell onto the tracks at Redhill station, Surrey.

item.title: Manchester United stand by Harry Maguire after 21-month suspended sentence was handed to him
item.description: Manchester United have revealed Harry Maguire will appeal against the guilty verdict handed to him for attacking and bribing Greek police and they have called for a 'full and fair' hearing.

item.title: Fitbit unveils new smartwatch called Sense that measures stress levels
item.description: Fitbit unveiled a new smartwatch capable of determining the wearer's stress levels by monitoring heart rate and skin temperature. Called Sense, it ships in Sept for $329.95.

item.title: Floating Apple Store next to Singapore's Marina Bay Sands Hotel
item.description: Apple is set to open its first floating Apple Store, a massive silver orb located near Singapore's Marina Bay Sands Hotel. It will gently glow at night, a nod to the paper lanterns used in local fall festivals.

item.title: Four men who blasted compressed air into a friend's RECTUM are jailed
item.description: The victim had passed out at a party in Norway in 2018 and was unable to defend himself when five fellow revellers came up with the scheme to blast air into his rectum with an air compressor.

item.title: HMS Hermes - Britain's flagship during the Falklands - is sold for scrap
item.description: The HMS Hermes served as Britain's flagship in the Falklands before being sold to India in 1986 and renamed the INS Viraat, was decommissioned in 2017 and has now been sold for scrap.

item.title: Sweden uncovers 3,700 false positives from faulty Chinese-made coronavirus test kits
item.description: Sweden's Public Health Agency said the PCR kits, which test for an ongoing COVID-19 infection, were made in China by the company BGI Genomics and had been distributed worldwide.

item.title: Nottingham woman, 75, is the earliest known Covid-19 patient to catch the disease in the UK
item.description: Researchers from the University of Nottingham say the woman, who later became one of the first three people to die of the disease, may have caught it as early as February 9.

item.title: Britain's retail jobs bloodbath saw workers axed at the fastest pace since 2009
item.description: A survey by the Confederation of British Industry found that the number of retailers laying off and hiring staff over the past 12 months dropped to minus 45 per cent in August.

item.title: Ofqual chief regulator Sally Collier QUITS in wake of A-Level and GCSE grades chaos
item.description: Ms Collier, a career civil servant, had come in for criticism over the chaos that enveloped exam results for thousands of teenagers unable to sit tests because of coronavirus.

item.title: Melania Trump's closest aide says she has never heard First Lady trash her husband and Ivanka
item.description: Melania Trump's closet aide said she's never heard the first lady make any disparaging remarks about President Donald Trump or the first family after a report that there are tapes of Melania doing so.

item.title: Harry Maguire's girlfriend accuses Greek police of 'lying' and trying to 'ruin his reputation'
item.description: Fern Hawkins took to Twitter to rubbish accusations against her boyfriend Harry Maguire, 27, for an alleged bar brawl on the holiday island of Mykonos.

item.title: Fury as topless sunbathers are told to cover up their breasts by French police
item.description: Two gendarmes in the south of France sparked a public outcry after asking women who were sunbathing topless to get dressed, prompting politicians to call it 'a threat to our way of life'

item.title: Trump aide claims British baby Charlie Gard died because it was 'too expensive to keep him alive'
item.description: Natalie Harp, who has battled bone cancer, claimed in Washington last night that Britain's National Health Service decided it was 'too expensive and too cruel to keep him alive.'

item.title: Channel 4 will host 'Black Takeover Day' in 2021 as Big Breakfast returns for one-off special
item.description: From breakfast until late night, Channel 4 will disrupt its regular schedule and reimagine some of its biggest shows while also introducing new programmes led by black talent.

item.title: Nuneaton motorist spared jail after injuring driver when he deliberately crashed into a bridge
item.description: Christopher Farmer, 33, was charged with dangerous driving after he bounced his Mitsubishi Colt off a wall into the path of a vehicle being driven by Paul Swatman in Arley, Worcestershire.

item.title: Judge blasts £21,000-a-year boarding school for giving a reference to paedophile housemaster
item.description: Paul Stevens (pictured), 62, got a job in Kenya after a reference from Abberley Hall School in Worcestershire. He had already abused boys at the school and abused others in Africa.

item.title: Covid-19 quarantine rules to Tui refunds - the Holiday Guru solves traveller queries
item.description: The Holiday Guru is always on hand to answer your questions. And with the pandemic causing mass confusion among travellers, the Guru's advice has never been more sought after.

item.title: First picture of mother-of-three, 29, and father-of-two, 37, who died during Storm Ellen
item.description: Mother-of-three Tanya Jackson, 29, and Brett Rogers, a 37-year-old dad-of-two, were travelling through Derbyshire when their car skidded off the road and smashed into a tree on Saturday.

item.title: The families who dig up their dead relatives
item.description: Every August the Torja community in Panggala, Nort Toraja, South Sulawesi, re-dress their relatives' bodies, clean them, speak with them and even light them cigarettes.

item.title: EIGHT Met Police officers are now being probed for misconduct
item.description: Nicole Smallman, 26, and her half-sister Bibaa Henry, 47, were found dead in Fryent Country Park in Wembley, north west London , in June - two days after they were reported missing.

item.title: Ex-Renault Formula One boss Flavio Briatore, 70, is rushed to hospital
item.description: Flavio Briatore, 70, has complained over the past month about the Italian government's decision to close nightclubs are numbers of positive coronavirus cases in the country began to rise.

item.title: More people are dying than expected in England and Wales for first time in two months
item.description: Data from the Office for National Statistics showed that the number of people dying of Covid-19 each week has been falling constantly since April.

item.title: Girl, five, dies while waiting for a heart transplant after being diagnosed with rare condition
item.description: The devastated family of Thalia-Beau Wright, who was diagnosed with restrictive cardiomyopathy in 2018, announced yesterday that the youngster had succumbed to the rare illness.

item.title: Google's UK boss insists tech giant will 'always pay tax it is required to'
item.description: Managing director Ronan Harris made the pledge on ITV's Good Morning Britain today after MPs previously described the company's tax payment as 'insulting when other businesses are struggling'.

item.title: Lady Frederick Windsor says Princess Beatrice 'looked exquisite on her wedding day'
item.description: Sophie Winkleman, 40, who is married to Lord Frederick Windsor, 41, the son of the Queen's first cousin, Prince Michael of Kent, branded Princess Beatrice a 'heavenly girl' when speaking to Hello.

item.title: 'Nonsense': Boris Johnson rubbishes claim he is planning to QUIT as PM in six months
item.description: Sir Humphrey Wakefield, whose journalist daughter Mary is married to Dominic Cummings, is said to have made the claim to a holidaymaker who visited his castle in Northumberland.
item.media:credit: Jenney Goodall/ Wimbledon Village Stabes www.wvstables.com

item.title: Healthy pregnant women are not more vulnerable to Covid-19 and do not fall more seriously ill
item.description: Researchers looked at a total of 1.7million women from the UK, US and Sweden, 56,000 of whom were pregnant, finding no differences in the rate of infection or hospitalisation with Covid-19.

item.title: Facebook hiring 'attempts to influence UK Government policy'
item.description: The social media giant has reportedly used its financial clout to poach 10 former officials who worked on online regulation in recent months.

item.title: Lewis Burton enjoys Ibiza after Caroline Flack's mother's attack
item.description: The former tennis player, 28, put on an extremely amorous display with the bikini-clad beauty as they enjoyed the final days of their sunny getaway, hours after another tense exchange.

item.title: Blood transfusions could protect stroke patients from brain damage, mouse trial shows
item.description: Researchers from the US found that mice given induced strokes had reduced symptoms after being given an injection of blood from a healthy peer.

item.title: Kremlin dismisses claims that Putin was behind Alexei Navalny's 'poisoning'
item.description: Friends of Alexei Navalny (pictured) have pointed the finger at Putin after the opposition leader fell ill on a flight in Siberia and was airlifted to Berlin in a critical condition.

item.title: Canary Islands:Illegal immigrant arrivals 600% higher than 2019
item.description: Illegal migration to the chain of volcanic islands in the Atlantic Ocean, has risen over six-fold this year compared to the same time last year, to 3,448 people as of August 16.

item.title: Nurse, 33, is fined £150 for 'fly-tipping' after leaving free apples outside her home for passers-by
item.description: Lydia Farrell said she was 'disheartened' that a council would fine someone doing a good deed. Ealing Council, in west London, has said it will withdraw the fine following backlash.

item.title: Crash survivor's eulogy at funeral of her husband and children
item.description: Geraldine Mullan, 45, lost her husband John Mullan, 49, and children Tomas, 14, and Amelia, six, when their car plunged off the road into Lough Foyle in Donegal, Ireland, last week.

item.title: Coronavirus: New powers to close Birmingham bars and restaurants which flout rules
item.description: Birmingham City Council has announced that as of Wednesday it will have the ability to investigate reports of premises failing to adhere to Covid-19 guidance.

item.title: Study to find out whether mouthwash can reduce spread of Covid-19
item.description: Covid-19 patients at the University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff will take part in new research to find out if it has the potential to reduce the levels of the virus in saliva.

item.title: Dutch and Belgian patients re-infected with Covid-19 after recovery
item.description: The cases - reported by local media - follow yesterday's landmark report of a Hong Kong man who was re-infected four and a half months after he was originally struck down.

item.title: University Challenge contestant with a 'thousand yard stare' destroys rival team
item.description: Oxford History student Seoan Webb has been dubbed star of the new series of University Challenge after he blew his peers out of the water in the match against Bristol University.

item.title: Nora Quoirin inquest is told police searched multiple houses during hunt
item.description: Senior police official Mohamad Nor Marzukee Besar told a court in Seremban city today that the family identified three houses where they thought the child might be held.

item.title: Mansion linked to Spain's King Juan Carlos is plagued by 'incidents'
item.description: Lawyers for Corinna Larsen, the former mistress of King Juan Carlos I and the owner of the Chyknell Hall Estate in Shropshire, spoke of 'a number of incidents' at the estate.
